article_title: Competing visions of Texas on November ballot
article_text:
Competing visions of Texas on November ballot What's next for Texas a deciding factor for voters

Photo: Marie D. De Jesus, Staff ﻿Gubernatorial candidates Greg Abbott and Wendy Davis﻿ are...

AUSTIN - In her quest to become Texas' third woman governor, Democratic Sen. Wendy Davis is harkening back to the days when Ann Richards won the top job in 1990, campaigning to take back the Capitol for the people.

article_metadata.description: AUSTIN - In her quest to become Texas' third woman governor, Democratic Sen. Wendy Davis is harkening back to the days when Ann Richards won the top job in 1990, campaigning to take back the Capitol for the people.  In measuring the two candidates for governor as the Nov. 4 general election nears, voters will find divergent visions for the Lone Star State.  Nick Davis, a Round Rock construction project supervisor, said he has perused the websites of both candidates and is leaning toward Abbott, although he admitted he is not particularly happy with Texas' current state after a decade of Republican leadership.  Abbott opposes the expansion of federal health programs and supports repeal of Obamacare, saying there are better ways to ensure more Texans get proper health care.  Davis supports expanding Medicaid to cover more low-income Texans, pointing out the state would get an estimated $100 billion in federal money over 10 years with an investment of just $15.6 billion.  Abbott wants to tighten state ethics laws to prohibit lawmakers from serving as bond counsel to public entities, an obvious dig at Davis' past legal work.  Davis wants more public disclosure about hazardous-chemical caches at plants, slamming Abbott over a ruling that state agencies cannot release previously public records because of a 2003 Homeland Security law to protect against terrorists.  [...] voters will make up their minds in their own way.
article_metadata.author.name: By Mike Ward  and Peggy Fikac

Nick Davis, a Round Rock construction project supervisor, said he has perused the websites of both candidates and is leaning toward Abbott, although he admitted he is not particularly happy with Texas' current state after a decade of Republican leadership.  Abbott opposes the expansion of federal health programs and supports repeal of Obamacare, saying there are better ways to ensure more Texans get proper health care. Davis wants more public disclosure about hazardous-chemical caches at plants, slamming Abbott over a ruling that state agencies cannot release previously public records because of a 2003 Homeland Security law to protect against terrorists.  [...] voters will make up their minds in their own way.
